Therefore, they were unable to return to Earth as they would pass through it. Willard's dream of walking on Earth once more and experiencing its beauty was shattered, and he realized that they were essentially ghosts on the Ghost Ship. The crew's purpose of finding a suitable planet to live on was not fulfilled, as their ship had become a spectral existence in space.

In the story "The Giants Return," the captain's decision to return to Earth instead of heading towards Omega Centauri was primarily driven by his own personal circumstances and the discovery of a derelict starship. The captain had been relieved of his command due to an illness that was slowly spreading from his hands, making him look much older than his actual age. The Foundation refused to give him another ship, leaving him with no other options but to retire with a spaceman's pension. 

When the captain and his crew came across a massive derelict starship drifting in space, they saw it as an opportunity to salvage its valuable components and make a fortune. The ship, with its gargantuan proportions and alien-like appearance, had been severely damaged and appeared to have been drifting for millions of years. Despite the risks and unknown origins of the ship, the captain saw it as a chance to claim the valuable resources it possessed.

However, upon closer inspection, the boarding party discovered that the ship had been so extensively damaged that there was little left of value inside. Disappointed but determined, the captain decided to bring the ship back to Callisto for salvage, even if it was just the hull and a few remaining storage compartments. 

It was during the examination of the ship's metal hull that the captain made a remarkable discovery. The metal, which had a yellowish tinge, had transformed into gold. This unexpected transmutation of the metal sparked the captain's excitement, as he realized that there were tons of this valuable metal just waiting to be collected outside the ship. This discovery further fueled his desire to return to Earth and claim the treasure, as the gold held the promise of immense wealth and a chance to overcome the difficulties he faced due to his illness.

In light of these circumstances, the captain's decision to return to Earth instead of continuing towards Omega Centauri was driven by his personal need for financial security and the opportunity to claim the newfound gold treasure from the derelict starship.

The Blue Behemoth is a science fantasy story by Walter M. Miller, Jr. The story follows Jon Karyl, a wayfarer who returns from a far country to his wife and family. However, his return is not a shining experience but rather shadowed by Time's relentless tyranny. In his absence, changes have occurred that lead to tragedy and despair. The story is told with no pulling of punches and astounds the reader with its adroit unfolding.

The story begins with Jon following a Steel-Blue, an extra-terrestrial race, through a sundered lock of a space station. They engage in a conversation where the Steel-Blue reveals that they are in the system for the same reason Earthmen are reaching out farther into their system - they need living room. The Steel-Blues plan to use strategically placed planets for their use.

Jon realizes that this invasion by extra-terrestrials is the answer to the scientists' warning about other races in the universe. He tries to warn Earth but is uncertain if his thoughts can be understood by the Steel-Blues. He follows the Steel-Blue into the invaders' space ship, wondering how he can warn Earth before it's too late.

Inside the ship, Jon navigates through dark corridors with the Steel-Blue as his guide. They eventually reach a circular room near the topside of the vessel where a more massive Steel-Blue orders the death penalty for Jon. However, Jon remains curious and determined, knowing he still has a stubray pistol for protection.

Meanwhile, Reno Ulrich's scout plane discovers a castaway colony on the planet Minos. The colony has unknowingly done tests for them by living on the planet. Bess, one of the members of the scout team, is excited about the discovery and wants to meet one of the inhabitants. She is given permission and eagerly heads to the medical department to meet the inhabitant.

In summary, The Blue Behemoth tells the story of Jon Karyl's return from a far country to his family, only to find tragedy and despair due to changes that occurred during his absence. The story also introduces the invasion of Earth by the Steel-Blues, an extra-terrestrial race in need of living space. The story explores the consequences of these events and follows the characters as they navigate through the challenges they face.

In "The Blue Behemoth," Bucky Shannon and Jig Bentley have differing opinions about their circus. Bucky sees their circus, Shannon's Imperial Circus, as a great show that is plagued by financial troubles and attachments. He believes that it is the greatest show in space and that they can turn their fortunes around. On the other hand, Jig is more realistic and critical of the circus. He has been with Shannon's Imperial Circus for eleven years and knows that it is lousy, mangy, and broken-down. He believes that nothing works, from the ship to the roustabouts, and that the circus stinks. Despite their differing opinions, they both encounter Simon Beamish, who offers to charter their circus for a tour of settlements along the Tehara Belt on Venus. Beamish, who claims to have independent means and a desire to provide entertainment to those less fortunate, offers them a retainer of one hundred Universal Credits. While Jig is skeptical of Beamish's intentions, Bucky is willing to take the offer, believing that there may be enough left to bribe a jury if necessary.

In "The Blue Behemoth," Jig's journey is characterized by a sense of longing for a home and a family. As a space rover, he is constantly on the move and has no real connection to a settled life. However, deep down, he yearns for the stability and love that comes with having a wife and children. This desire becomes even stronger when he encounters the Time Theater, a place where people can view different time periods. Jig is drawn to the idea of seeing Earth and experiencing different moments in history. He becomes excited at the possibility of viewing significant figures like Napoleon or Hitler, but realizes that the time period being showcased is not what he expected. Despite this disappointment, Jig remains hopeful that one day he will find a home and a family of his own.

The meeting between Jig, Bucky, and Beamish in "The Blue Behemoth" is significant because Beamish proposes to charter Shannon's Imperial Circus for a tour of several settlements along the Tehara Belt. This proposal is significant because it offers a potential solution to the financial troubles and imminent closure of the circus. Beamish, who claims to have independent means, wants to provide entertainment to towns along the Venusian frontiers where no proper entertainment has been available. This presents an opportunity for the circus to generate income and continue operating. However, there is also a sense of suspicion and uncertainty surrounding Beamish's intentions, as he seems to be hiding something and there are hints of a potential scam or crooked dealings. The meeting sets the stage for the conflicts and challenges that the characters will face as they navigate the uncertain future of the circus.

In the story, the initial location is a space station where Jon and Karyl encounter the Steel-Blues, a race of extra-terrestrials. The Steel-Blues explain that they are in the system for the same reason Earthmen are exploring space - they need living space and see Earth's strategically placed planets as opportunities for expansion. Jon realizes that this invasion by extra-terrestrials is the result of warnings from scientists who have been preaching preparedness for years. Despite the danger he faces, Jon follows the Steel-Blue into the invaders' spaceship, wondering how he can warn Earth. He is taken to a circular room where he is examined by another Steel-Blue before being sentenced to death. However, Jon remains curious about his situation, having taken on the job of a service station attendant to experience something new. Meanwhile, in another part of the story, Chip finds himself on a planetoid surrounded by a group of strangers after a crash. He demands to know what is happening and soon realizes that he has run afoul of the Lorelei's men, who have intercepted his message. The leader of the group interrogates Chip about the location of an ekalastron mine, and when Chip refuses to reveal the secret, he threatens to beat it out of him. In another part of the story, Ben, who has been haunted by visions and dreams, discovers a tri-dimensional photo of a red-bearded man on a bureau. He later learns that the man is Maggie's husband and that they are in need of an astrogator for their mission. Maggie explains that her husband is building a new base somewhere between Mercury and Pluto, and she has been recruiting people like Ben to join their cause.

The story "Spaceman on a Spree" is about a space rover named Willard who returns to Earth after being lost in space for thirteen years. He had left Earth on a space exploration mission with his friend Larry Dobbin, but their ship, the Mary Lou, never returned. Willard is the lone survivor and has been living in solitude on the ship, haunted by memories of his life on Earth.

Willard dreams of his life on Earth and longs to be reunited with his wife and family. He tries to erase the memories to ease his loneliness, but he finds that it's impossible. He also becomes aware of the legend of the Ghost Ship, a spaceship doomed to wander the Solar System, and wonders if it's just a product of his imagination or if there is some truth to it.

As the years pass, Willard loses track of time and becomes resigned to his solitary existence. He experiences moments of hope, like when he sees a passing rocket ship, only to realize it's the Ghost Ship mocking him. Eventually, he stops looking out the window, fearing that he might see the Ghost Ship and go mad.

Meanwhile, on Earth, Willard's son plans to build a new exploration ship named Mary Lou II in memory of his father. The story ends with Willard's retirement ceremony, where he receives a gold watch and contemplates his decision to retire and live a simple life on Earth, free from the loneliness and hardships of space travel.

In summary, "Spaceman on a Spree" is a story about the longing for home, the toll of solitude, and the choices one makes in pursuit of happiness and contentment. It explores the emotional and psychological effects of space travel and the human need for connection and belonging.

The story "Spaceman on a Spree" follows the protagonist, Si Pond, who has recently retired from his job as a space pilot in the Ultrawelfare State. Si decides to embark on a big spree to celebrate his retirement, intending to spend his accumulated wealth on various indulgences. He plans to make this spree different from previous ones by spending his money wisely and enjoying only the best experiences.

Meanwhile, another character, Grannie Annie, who is a science fiction writer known as Annabella C. Flowers, shows up unexpectedly at the Spacemen's Club, despite the strict rule against women entering. She is a quirky and eccentric individual who has gained fame and fortune from her science fiction novels, even though they may be considered dime novels by some. Grannie Annie and the protagonist, Billy-boy, catch up and discuss her recent book, "Guns for Ganymede."

The story takes a dramatic turn when Si Pond finds himself in a life-threatening situation. He is confronted by Heraal, who blames him for the death of a life-form and threatens him with violence. Just as Si is about to defend himself, Heraal unexpectedly impales himself on his own sword. In the story "Spaceman on a Spree," Gubelin and Perregaux plan to lure Pond back into the space program by appealing to his sense of adventure and offering him incentives. They recognize that Pond is the only trained space pilot in the world, and without him, it would take months or even years to train a new pilot. They believe that if they can convince Pond to return, it will help secure funding for the Department of Space Exploration and potentially spark a renewed interest in space travel. 

Gubelin and Perregaux understand that Pond is motivated by financial security and a desire for a comfortable life. They know that Pond retired because he felt he had enough shares of Basic to sustain his lifestyle, and he did not want to continue facing the dangers and hardships of space travel. Therefore, they come up with a plan to entice Pond back by finding a way to separate him from his accumulated nest egg. Overall, Gubelin and Perregaux are determined to convince Pond to return to the space program because they believe his expertise and experience are crucial. They understand his motivations and are willing to use whatever means necessary to persuade him to come back, recognizing that the future of space exploration depends on it.

In the story "Spaceman on a Spree," Seymour Pond is a space pilot. He was selected for this job based on his experience and qualifications. As a space pilot, his duties included conducting trips to various destinations such as the Moon, Venus, Mars, and the Jupiter satellites. He would spend long periods of time alone in space, dealing with the challenges of claustrophobia, monotony, boredom, and free fall. Despite the prestige and recognition that came with his job, Pond eventually decided to retire. He realized that living in a one-room mini-auto-apartment, equipped with an autochair, built-in autobar, and a wall-sized television screen, provided him with enough contentment and comfort. He no longer wanted to subject himself to the mental strain and isolation of space travel. Pond's retirement set back the Department of Space Exploration, as they didn't believe he had enough shares of Variable Basic to sustain himself. However, Pond had planned ahead and acquired enough Basic shares to support his desired lifestyle. He was content with his decision and no longer cared about the countdowns and blasts offs of space travel.

In the story "Spaceman on a Spree" by Mack Reynolds, the protagonist, Seymour Pond, is obsessed with wealth and fame. Pond's ambition and desire is to pilot the first manned rocket to the moon. He is fully prepared and dedicated to achieving this goal, going above and beyond in his preparations. However, Pond's retirement from space travel is met with a lackluster reward of a symbolic gold watch and a banquet, where speeches are given by important figures in the Department of Space Exploration. Pond is disappointed by this recognition and would have preferred a more tangible reward, such as shares of Variable Basic to add to his portfolio. He is aware that his retirement has set them back and that they did not believe he had enough shares to sustain himself. Despite their expectations, Pond has made the decision to retire with a limited crediting, rather than continue with more trips in the hopes of achieving a higher standard. Pond is confident in his financial security with enough Basic to sustain him, and he refuses to subject himself to the hardships and challenges of space travel again. The story "My Lady Greensleeves" follows the protagonist, Liam O'Leary, who is a captain of guards in the Estates-General Correctional Institution, also known as the Jug. He is investigating a detainee named Sue-Ann Bradley who refuses to mop her cell. As O'Leary questions Bradley, he learns that she was not informed about the task and was falsely accused of refusing to do it. O'Leary allows her to speak in her own defense, following the rules of the prison.

Meanwhile, another storyline unfolds as an old woman named Grannie Annie tells a man named Billy-boy about her experiences on Venus. The Green Flames have the ability to affect the brain of any living creature exposed to its gamma rays, inducing a sense of lassitude, lack of energy, and a desire for leadership or guidance. Grannie Annie discovers that there may still be a quantity of Green Flames in existence, which could potentially cause trouble if it falls into the wrong hands.

Grannie Annie's manuscript is stolen, leading her to believe that someone is trying to bring her plot into action. She suspects that the Green Flames have been made even more potent and are being transmitted en masse, causing riots and demands for a military dictatorship across various planets in the system. Grannie Annie and Billy-boy narrowly escape an assassination attempt and flee in a driverless hydrocar.

The story ends with an unrelated narrative from a character named Captain Midas, who has been relieved of his command due to a spreading illness. He reflects on the cursed nature of treasure and the bitter consequences he has faced.

In summary, "My Lady Greensleeves" involves multiple storylines, including Liam O'Leary's investigation of a detainee, Grannie Annie's discovery of the Green Flames and its potential dangers, and Captain Midas's tragic fate.

The story "Call Him Nemesis" revolves around a man named Bram who is a mysterious figure living in an isolated part of the country. The premise of "The Big Headache" is the discovery of a potential cure for headaches. Mitchell and Ferris believe they have developed a shot that can cure headaches caused by the constriction of blood vessels in the brain, which is caused by an over-production of the pituitary gland. They have bred a virus that feeds on pituitrin, the hormone responsible for the constriction, and can localize and stabilize it in the brain. The story revolves around their attempt to convince the renowned mathematician, Elliot Macklin, who suffers from severe migraines, to participate in their experiment.

The location of the events in "The Big Headache" is not explicitly stated in the story. In the story "The Big Headache," the main character, Elliot Macklin, is suffering from severe headaches, specifically migraines. The scientists, Mitchell and Ferris, approach Macklin with a potential solution to cure headaches using a virus that feeds on pituitrin, which causes the constriction of blood vessels in the brain. They believe that this virus can be used to relax the cerebral vessels and alleviate the pressure that causes headaches. However, Macklin's wife is hesitant about the treatment and prefers her husband to remain in his current state of lower intelligence because it brings him relief from the headaches. She is concerned about the potential risks and side effects of the treatment, particularly due to Macklin's history of vascular spasm. The Army officer, Colonel Carson, tries to convince her to allow the treatment, but she refuses and prioritizes her husband's well-being over restoring his intellectual abilities. In the end, Mitchell contacts Macklin directly and convinces him to come to the laboratory, suggesting that he bring Colonel Carson along as well.

In the story "The Big Headache," Ferris and Mitchell have developed an injection that they believe can cure headaches permanently. They explain to Macklin, a mathematician who suffers from severe migraines, that the injection targets the pressure effect caused by pituitrin in the brain. This pressure effect is the constriction of blood vessels in the telencephalon section of the frontal lobes, which is caused by an over-production of the pituitary gland. Ferris and Mitchell have artificially bred a virus that feeds on pituitrin, and this virus can be localized and stabilized in the brain cells. By introducing the virus into the brain, it relaxes the cerebral vessels and prevents the cerebrospinal fluid from creating pressure in the brain cavities. This alleviates the cause of headaches and provides a potential permanent cure. Macklin is intrigued by this discovery and expresses his desire to try the injection to relieve his migraines. Ferris assures him that their discovery will work and replace the need for other headache medications like ergotamine tartrate.

In "The Big Headache," the characters respond positively to the option of using a cure for headaches. Mitchell, Ferris, and Macklin discuss the possibility of a simple injection that could cure headaches forever. They believe that the cause of headaches is the pressure effect caused by pituitrin in the brain, which is the constriction of blood vessels in the telencephalon section of the frontal lobes. They have artificially bred a virus that feeds on pituitrin and can relax the cerebral vessels, relieving the pressure that causes headaches.

Macklin, who suffers from severe migraines, is intrigued by the idea of a cure and expresses his desire to remove his curse. He is willing to try the cure and stop using the medication that makes him sick. Mitchell and Ferris assure him that their discovery will work and provide relief from headaches.

While Macklin acknowledges that there may be certain benefits to the constriction of blood vessels in certain areas, he is willing to try the cure and sees it as a potential solution to his debilitating migraines. The story ends with Macklin expressing his interest in being part of the experiment and finding relief from his headaches.

Overall, the characters in "The Big Headache" respond positively to the option of using a cure for headaches and are hopeful that it will provide relief from the pain and suffering caused by migraines.

In the story "The Long Remembered Thunder," Tremaine discovers that Bram is a foreigner who is suspected of being a communist.
